frameDefinitions: A Speaker conveys a Message to an Experiencer in order to reassure them about a Situation; Medium and the Means of the communication also may be expressed.

The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.
An Agent, Actor, Entity, or Medium causes a Phenomenon to be perceived by a Perceiver.
An Agent  places a Component in a Fixed_location so that the Component is attached and interconnected and thereby functional.
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
frameExamples: We <t>reassured</t> him that his decision was sound.
The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
Displays were given an overhaul in the 1950s, with canopies <t>installed</t> above the Christmas counters to allow calendar and gift bows to be displayed. CNI
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
listRoleDefinitions: The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to reassure another person.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> receives reassurance from the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Speaker</fen> wants the <fen>Experiencer</fen> to believe in order to feel reassured.
The <fen>Situation</fen> is the problem plaguing the <fen>Experiencer</fen>, about which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  reassures them.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the reassurance takes place.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally creates a situation in which the <fen>Perceiver</fen> observes or experiences the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is an entity or idea that is perceived by the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.
The <fen>Perceiver</fen> is made to have a perceptual experience by the <fen>Agent</fen>.
An <fen>Actor</fen> is a sentient being who is exhibiting, possibly uninintentionally, some <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
An object that has some association with a <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Medium</fen> through which a <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is expressed.
When the event occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the perception of the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person (or other force) that installs the <fen>Component</fen>.
The <fen>Component</fen> is the object that is placed in a <fen>Fixed_location</fen>.
The <fen>Fixed_location</fen> is the location where the <fen>Component</fen> is placed and to which it is attached so as to be useful.
The time period in which the <fen>Component</fen> is installed.
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the installation occurs.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
listRoleExamples: <fex>He</fex> reassured her that she was his favorite ice-skating star.
He tried to reassure <fex>his potential customers</fex> that his company not only offered the best service, but also the most competitive prices.
How do you reassure them <fex>that you really like them</fex>?
The policeman reassured him <fex>about the safety of the neighborhood</fex>.
<fex>The robber</fex> tied Harry to the chair.
The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.
The robber tied Harry <fex>to the chair</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair  <fex>with a rope</fex>.
The robber tied <fex>Harry's ankles</fex> together.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>at midnight</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>in the basement</fex>.
<fex>John</fex> installed it last night on my Gentoo system and everything is going fine so far.
My plumber installed <fex>the shower pan</fex>.

I assembled the fuel tank using a vent line and a supply line, and then I installed
the tank <fex>in the fuselage</fex>.
When we installed our hood <fex>last month</fex>, the folks at Dallas Auto Body painted our roll pan at the same time.
When I installed the server <fex>there</fex> last winter they only had two rows of racks, mostly empty.
Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Independently Powered Electric Multiple Unit
